Award.AwardTitle: Laboratory Studies of Oxygen Atom Recombination in Nitrogen at Mesospheric Temperatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports laboratory experiments to study the kinetics of the process of oxygen atom recombination in a molecular nitrogen environment and the pathways that lead to excited states of molecular oxygen (O2) at temperatures relevant to the Earth's mesosphere. The project will supply basic physical measurements needed to interpret and model important processes in the upper atmosphere, such as O2 airglow and atmospheric dynamics. In addition to observational and theoretical studies of Aeronomy, this work could benefit research on planetary atmospheres. The project will contribute to the training and research experience of one or more postdoctoral fellows and undergraduate students.
The role of collisional relaxation, the temperature-dependent recombination rate coefficient, the dominant energy flow pathways, and the resulting O2 excited state yields will be studied. These measurements are needed for a quantitative understanding and reliable modeling of the atmosphere and its airglow emissions. Knowledge of the details relevant to the production of excited O2 is critical input for the study and modeling of atmospheric composition, energy transfer, airglow, and transport dynamics. The experimental methodology involves the photoinitiation of O-atom recombination in a suitable bath gas by an ultraviolet radiation pulse from an excimer laser. Fluorescence and resonance-enhanced multiphoton ionization (REMPI) techniques are used to monitor the decay of the O-atom population and detect excited O2 molecules, thus providing insight into the relevant removal rate coefficients, energy flow pathways, and yields of the excited O2 states produced following recombination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At night, the Earth's upper atmospheric region emits a weak chemiluminescence called nightglow. Excited molecular species such as molecular oxygen and hydroxyl are prominent examples of terrestrial nightglow emitters. The process of oxygen atom three-body recombination is considered a major source of nightglow emissions because it generates all low-lying excited electronic states of molecular oxygen. This process is not a bimolecular reaction, but instead requires the interaction of a third body in order to remove excess chemical energy and stabilize the nascent oxygen molecule. Despite numerous research efforts during the past several decades, the mechanistic details and quantitative kinetics of the recombination of atomic oxygen are still elusive. We are pursuing a research program with an emphasis on laser-based laboratory measurements to advance knowledge of the Earth’s nightglow. Our experiments investigated collisions between oxygen atoms in a bath gas containing mixtures of atmospheric gases. Nitrogen and oxygen are most relevant for conditions in the upper atmosphere of the Earth, whereas carbon dioxide is most important for the atmospheres of Mars and Venus. We also investigated the interaction of highly vibrationally excited hydroxyl radical, OH(v), ground-state oxygen atoms. A particularly significant development is the first demonstration in the laboratory of a pathway for fast, multi-quantum vibrational relaxation of OH(v) by O atoms. This energy transfer process represents a major revision to previous literature reports and recommended model inputs. It has significant implications for atmospheric models accounting for nightglow emissions. This work resolved long-standing discrepancies between model calculations and observations of the nighttime infrared emission of carbon dioxide at 4.3 micrometers. In this manner, our measurements made an impact in the way we understand energy balance in the upper atmosphere.

In summary, the results of our research are essential input for atmospheric models and for a reliable quantitative interpretation of the nightglow emissions observed in Earth’s upper atmosphere. They are also of potential for other planetary atmospheres, and even atmospheres of extrasolar planets. Finally, this project provided research training and educational opportunities for one undergraduate student and one post-doctoral fellow. The undergraduate student participated at our NSF-supported Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site.
